title: 104_hr2970
content:
The Act is titled the "International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1996". It includes findings related to international arbitration. The Congress finds that international arbitration is crucial for US persons conducting business globally, especially in countries with unreliable legal systems. The enforcement of foreign arbitral awards is essential for the effectiveness of international arbitration. Foreign states violate the Convention by refusing to enforce foreign arbitral awards or impairing the ability to collect them. It is in the interest of the United States to maintain the reliability of international arbitration and protect US persons from economic injury. Creating a judicial remedy for US persons injured by foreign states is in the national interest. Judicial remedy for US persons injured by foreign states due to Convention violations to enforce judgments. The purpose of this Act is to create a civil remedy against foreign states for violating the Convention and injuring United States persons by prohibiting the enforcement of foreign arbitral awards in favor of such persons or impairing their ability to collect such awards. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

The term "Convention" refers to the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards, done at New York on June 10, 1958. The term "United States person" includes US citizens, permanent residents, and entities majority-owned by them. A "foreign arbitral award" is any award covered by the Convention.

SEC. 5. LIABILITY FOR VIOLATION OF THE CONVENTION. Any foreign state certified by the President for injuring a US person through a violation of the Convention on a foreign arbitral award is liable for damages including the award amount, interest, attorney's fees, and costs. Actions can be taken for awards before or after the Act's enactment. Presidential certification is required for the injury. If a foreign state fails to enforce a foreign arbitral award in favor of a US person in violation of the Convention, or impedes the enforcement of the award, the US person must exhaust all remedies in the foreign state before seeking damages. Presidential certification is required for the injury. The Presidential certification of a US person's injury by a foreign state's violation of the Convention establishes a presumption of the violation and the equivalent damages. District courts have exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions involving violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1996 amends the table of sections for chapter 85 of title 28, United States Code, regarding civil actions involving violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1996 amends Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, to include civil actions related to violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. It also amends Section 1610(a) to specify that there is no immunity from attachment or execution in such cases. The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1996 amends Section 1610(b) of title 28, United States Code, to allow judgments or attachments related to claims where the foreign state is not immune under section 1605(a)(7). The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1996 amends Section 1610(b) of title 28, United States Code, allowing actions to be brought within one year after the President's certification under subsection (b) on which the action is based.
